imagecat-rails.title: Allow copy_images to take a list of images to sync.
Figure out which images we are missing on AWS and copy them up

comments.body:
Ran the following, ignore the `;nil`, that was me running this in IRB:

```ruby
files = Dir.glob("tmp/*.csv")
all_lines = files.flat_map do |f|
  File.read(f).split("\n").map do |entry|
    corrected = entry.split(",").last.gsub("imagecat-","").gsub('"', "").gsub("-", "/").gsub(/tif$/, "tiff")
    "./#{corrected}"
  end
end; nil
set = Set.new(all_lines); nil
local_files = File.read("tmp/file_list.txt").split("\n"); nil
local_files = Set.new(local_files); nil
diff = local_files - set; nil
```
6,557 missed files.

[missing_files.txt](https://github.com/pulibrary/imagecat-rails/files/12886518/missing_files.txt)

Those 6,557 have been uploaded to puliiif-production and puliiif-staging via #192. There were some weird permission things (files in tmp were owned by pulsys, but I had to run commands as deploy) so I had to do some permission stuff to get it to upload, but they're there now.
Ah - the files weren't missing, they just aren't called `imagecat-disk` - they're `imagecat-temp` or `imagecat-temp2` or `imagecat-temp3`, so the above `s3` prefix command wasn't right.

The reason is there are `temp` directories that look like old staging directories. For example: `/var/tmp/imagecat/disk20/temp2/0048/A2380/0000.0045.tiff`.

There's also a `/var/tmp/imagecat/disk20/0048/A2380/` and they're exactly the same. I think we can safely ignore the `temp` dirs:

`diff <(ls /var/tmp/imagecat/disk20/temp2/0048/A2380/) <(ls)` (empty)

oawaiver.title: OAWaiver e-mail messages are not being sent due to a mailer configuration error

comments.body:
Currently the Rails application is only being actively served from `oawaiver-prod2.princeton.edu`:

```bash
pulsys@oawaiver-prod2:~$ curl http://localhost:80/ | head
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100<!DOCTYPE html> 0    0     0      0      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--     0
  7058    0  7058    0     0   931k      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  984k
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
    <meta name="Generator" content="Waiver Database: Revision: 0.0.1"/>

    <title>Open Access Waiver | Princeton University Library</title>
    <!-- Ajax Autocomplete Styling -->
pulsys@oawaiver-prod2:~$
```

I can also confirm that the SMPT host is responding, and that inbound connections are accepted from the `oawaiver-prod2` host:

```bash
deploy@oawaiver-prod2:~$ nc -v -u lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu 587
Connection to lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu (...) 587 port [udp/*] succeeded!
```

The issue appears to be that TCP traffic over port 25 is blocked, however, UDP traffic is *not* blocked:

```bash
deploy@oawaiver-prod2:~$ nc -v -u lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu 25
Connection to lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu (...) 25 port [udp/*] succeeded!
^C
deploy@oawaiver-prod2:~$ nc -v lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu 25
nc: connect to lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu (...) port 25 (tcp) failed: No route to host
deploy@oawaiver-prod2:~$ nc -v -u lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu 25
Connection to lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu (...) 25 port [udp/*] succeeded!
```

TCP traffic is enabled for inbound connections to the SMPT host from the PDC Describe production hosts, and hence, I am going to request that this be advanced with a firewall update request:

```bash
deploy@pdc-describe-prod1:~$ nc -v -u lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu 25
Connection to lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu (...) 25 port [udp/*] succeeded!
^C
deploy@pdc-describe-prod1:~$ nc -v lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu 25
Connection to lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu (...) 25 port [tcp/smtp] succeeded!
220 lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu ESMTP Sendmail 8.14.4/8.14.4; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 11:49:10 -0400
^C
```

https://princeton.service-now.com/sc_task.do?sys_id=6681399687bd7910419b85dd0ebb358f&sysparm_view=&sysparm_domain=null&sysparm_domain_scope=null is currently tracking the request, and this is currently in progress to be fulfilled.
I have ensured that the priority is set to `High` for this SN@P ticket, and have requested an update (as well as offered to directly assist if I could).

I have also confirmed that this still may well be a firewall issue:

```bash
deploy@oawaiver-prod2:~$ nc -v lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu 25
nc: connect to lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu (...) port 25 (tcp) failed: No route to host
deploy@oawaiver-prod2:~$ nc -v -u lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu 25
Connection to lib-ponyexpr.princeton.edu (...) 25 port [udp/*] succeeded!
```
handling this outside of OL https://github.com/pulibrary/libapps/pull/25
Closing as duplicate.
Oct 12 9:20am: Still waiting for approval.

orcid_princeton.title: Added information about ORCID branding to README

comments.body: Resolved conflict in README.md and approved.

Looks like this is the gem that lets us authenticate to orcid and get a token: https://github.com/datacite/omniauth-orcid

We need to register our application (there is a staging and a production environment). For full access we need to be organization orcid members, and I've asked on slack for confirmation that this is so.

We need to provide a contact email address and a secondary email address, as well as the URLs the application will use and the redirect urls that omniauth will use. Form is here, for reference: https://info.orcid.org/register-a-client-application-production-member-api/

The page also says we should expect some lead time:

> Note: This process is not fully automated. There may be a delay before we respond to you with credentials or a demo request after you complete this form.

There appears to be pretty good documentation for how to configure this in rails:
https://github.com/datacite/omniauth-orcid#rails
